Bonrstein and Clark should not be on the field, pure and simple. Neither is a world-level player, in spite of their work rate. Edu and Torres not even being seen on the pitch worries me. If this is BB's likely choices for central midfield on Saturday, MB backed by Clark...hope and pray our attack pulls out a result in a most likely high scoring game.

Findley is quick but of only journeyman MLS quaIity. How many touches that went wayward in front of goal? Gomez touches the ball once and it's in the back of the net. I'll take quality finishing/passing over speed. Buddle looks to be a diamond in the rough. Keep in mind that Jozy has experience running at defenders with pace (that was his role with Angel at NYRB and what Villareal had in mind when they bought him). I think Buddle and Jozy at the top would create some surprises, particularly with Donavan and Dempsey free to roam.
We still love Ray in Milwaukee... sweetness personified. Great to see him have another moment in the spotlight and burn the dreaded Anti-Jordan, Kobe.

i only watched the 4th quarter. in a close game @LA i saw 5 blown calls against LA.
i am not rooting for LA but these were atrocious. nate rob clearly traveled but celtics ball. garnett clearly knocked the ball out of bounds, but again celtics ball. and so on. after the atrocious game 2 against Orlando, when the refs failed to call time out with 7 seconds left, and Then failed to correct their error, this long time NBA fan can only question the honesty of these games. note, the tv revenue is up with this matchup, as covered by this paper, and also note how these teams acquired Pau and Allen, etc as if by magic. i guess it will go seven. LOL!

The US has spent years playing Tic Tac Toe in its attempts to broker peace in the Middle East, and we're starting to learn the concept of futility. As a tax payer, I'd rather see my tax dollars go to countries for humanitarian purposes rather than supporting Israel's defense.

Israel has proven itself more than capable of defending itself. The international community largely disagrees with Israel's tactics now thanks to the recent events like the flotilla attack, Lebanon, Israel's attempt to develop another settlement, their position on nukes, etc.), so I think it's high time we let Israel stand on their own. US leadership has long believed our realationship with democratic Israel will help us and the world reach a global democracy, but I'd ask what has Israel done (aside from for its own self-interest) to promote global democracy? I'd ask what significant steps from either side demonstrate a genuine desire for peace? The problem is the US picked a side, and now it's time to stop enabling bad behavior.

We can't save Israel. Maintaining an alliance with Israel has neither promoted democracy or kept America safer. If anything, it has hurt us and created an even greater global divide.

Many years ago, I read the chilling account of "The Handmaid's Tale," by Margaret Atwood.  This brilliant and terrifying novel, supposedly based on Ms. Atwood’s observations of women’s plight in Afghanistan and Iran, dispels the perception that such things cannot happen in the U.S.  When women suffer in any culture, all people on the planet suffer.  It behooves all free societies to support any efforts to liberate those who struggle in bondage anywhere in the world because of color, religious beliefs, gender, education and other differences.  Those who state that the education and freedom of women worldwide improves the economy and quality of life for all are correct; their voices should be raised louder and longer.

The Bible is not a source of international law. If each country were to invoke religious or historic arguments to define its borders, the whole world would be immersed in endless wars. However, in the last 4000 years the world has developed a set of norms, not perfect, but aimed at ensuring a peaceful coexistence between States. One of those norms is the definition of aggression approved by the General Assembly of the United Nations with the affirmative votes of ALL the member States, including Israel and the United States. According to it, Israel is an aggressor and an invading country. The Palestinians have all the right to fight to recover their land. Nevertheless, the PLO recognized the right of Israel to exist, something Israel did not regarding a Palestinian State. Hamas represent only the last example of the desperation of the Palestinian people in dealing with an aggressive and  fundamentalist State. Take note recdds.

Not to worry, the fifty thousand that will remain in Iraq as long as the Marines have stayed on Okinawa, will bid the others good-bye as they head to Afganistan, to stay there at least twice as long as the Marines have stayed on Okinawa.

The United States does not give up Empire building easily.

Leslie I understand your husband thinks he made friends in Iraq but think about that objectively for a moment. Wouldn't you placate and smile at the guy with they raybands and the assault rifle who could put your head in a burlap sack and make you disappear, or just shoot you dead.
Honestly how naive can u be. Your husband isn't making friends and having interesting experiences with foreign cultures. He's killing people for money.
That's the realpolitik.
And who cares if he develops character or mental and emotional stamina. So do convicts. Aren't there better ways to do that?
Military is NOT an honorable profession. Members of the military kill people for money or are accessories to that killing. Killing people is never honorable.

p.s. steve: I do know people in the military and not just the emotionally disturbed alcoholics I have to avoid at the bar.

A difficult question.

When the Palestinians try peace, Israel uses the peace to build as many illegal settlements as they can and make life miserable for Palestinians to encourage them to emigrate.

When the Palestinians fight back, Israel accuses them of being terrorists and kill more of them.
This problem could easily be solved if the US Government had the will, but we all know about the politics in the US about supporting Israel.

In the long run, Israel will lose this struggle because the US will eventually stop supporting Israel. “Why” you ask? For the same reason that the US pulled out of Vietnam. When the American people understand how much it is costing them ... Sept 11 2001, Afghanistan, Iraq, billions of dollars in aid to Israel each year, the loss US friends in Europe and elsewhere, the threat of a terrorist nuclear attack on US soil ... they will demand a stop. Unfortunately, Americans don’t actually do anything until they see the bodies coming home so my guess is that it will take a nuclear bomb detonated in a US city to make Americans wakeup to the cost.
UrbanSpoon's Rezbook app is for the iPad. There doesn't seem to be a version yet for smart phones.

Imagine a future where our cities won't be blighted by the sight Walmart and Target stores.  All of these basic necessities will arrive at our door when we need them thanks to the efficient work of shipping and handling robots.  Someone should do a carbon footprint analysis of this service vs. one driving to Walmart, where parking lots, climate control, bright lights, signs and cash registers are required in addition to the delivery trucks to get it to the store.
If you buy an iPad today to be grandfathered in on the unlimited plan, do you know if this would still apply if a newer iPad is released down the road?

Question: This doesn't necessarily deal w/the iPad, but; what about upgrades?  If a consumer purchased an "iPhone" before June 7th, and wants to upgrade to a 4G phone, will the consumer still be able to maintain the unlimited plan?
As another alice.com & drugstore.com user, I wonder why more research wasn't done for this article, showing the reader what else is available out there.

I was planning on purchasing an 3G iPad, but with the removal of the unlimited data plan, I will not be purchasing an iPad at all. So Apple loses a sale and AT&T loses $30 a month. I hope I'm not the only one to make such a decision.

I think AT&T is doing this to counter data usage by next generation iPhone users. This article talks in detail about AT&T's true motive.
http://techztalk.com...

The issue I am more concerned about is that iPhone tethering apparently cannot be used with the iPad. Seems to me that having tethering as an option with the Wi-Fi-only iPad would be a smart policy.  iPad users can sip from their unused iPhone data allocation when they  occasionally  need to use the iPad and Wi-Fi is not available.

That's it! I'm keeping my Unlimited plan and turning on audio/video streaming continuously 24/7 to use as much data as my iphone can... just let it run and suck as many bits. I urge all users to do the same!

This is much better Mr Pouge. It is truly a bait and switch.  One which I cannot see a way ATT and Apple could get out of.  Being it was a initial launch of a product and done a mere 40 days after the launch makes them greedy.  Don't get me wrong, I love ATTs coverage.  I say that if I did not want a drop call now and again I could talk on a landline.  I even have no issue with ATT customer service.  Not well informed all the time but always courteous to me.  And I am a true Apple fan but together we have a love hate relationship right now.  I paid an extra $130 for the 3G "just in case I wanted to use the unlimited plan" but now I can only keep it if I pay the 30 dollars without lapse.  I just came from the Sprint store and looked at the Evo.  Its shiny for sure.  But I don't know how their coverage is. W But I get 30 days to try at least.  I don't want to leave ATT but I feel as though I've been cheated. They just try to nickel and dime you to death.  Anyone that ordered the iPad or had it prior to change of terms should get to stay with terms they thought they were getting or someone ought to give the option to exchange or return.

The $15 iPad plan is 250 MB, not 200 MB.

Also, you forgot one other odd, but not quite sleazy, part of these new plans. For $25 you get 2 GB (roughly 2000 MB). For $15 you get 200 MB (10% of the higher plan). I'm okay with that but here is the odd part. If you want to add to that $15 plan they want to charge you another $15 to add another 200 MB.

So, $25 for 2000 MB
$30 for 400 MB

Why not just bump users up to the $25 plan if they go over?
A few corrections.  It's $10 for an iditional GB not 2.  Also the original iPad plan was for 250 megs, and they said the $30 plan was truely unlimited with no cap.

Can anyone clear up what seems like a contradiction? If this won't affect that many consumers, why would they be doing it? If most people aren't using that much - (NOTE QUOTES: "AT&T said 98 percent of its smart-phone customers use less than 2 GB of data each month, which means they will pay less for data use...") And I totally agree with the main comments above, that this discourages use while the network spirals to inadequacy. Hasn't AT&T made a TON of cash as the exclusive iPhone/iPad service carrier? Now they are whining because people want to use their devices and need data capacity. Apple should drop them ASAP, or at least provoke some competition by adding alternate licensed carrier. It's tarnishing the i-device experience.

"For most consumers this is a good deal," because modest monthly data use would qualify them for a cheaper plan, said Mike Gikas, senior editor at Consumer Reports.")

It's slimy and Apple seems to be contributing. The Apple store STILL says that we can have unlimited start/stop 3G

"In the United States, 3G service is available through a breakthrough deal with AT&T. You choose the amount of data per month you want to buy — 250MB or unlimited. If you choose the 250MB plan, you’ll receive onscreen messages as you get close to your monthly data limit so you can decide whether to turn off 3G or upgrade to the unlimited plan. Best of all, there’s no long-term contract. So if you have a business trip or vacation approaching, just sign up for the month you’ll be traveling and cancel when you get back. You don’t need to visit a store to get 3G service. You can sign up, check your data usage, manage your account, or cancel your service — all from your iPad."

I get why AT&T does it, but why is Apple also now misleading us?

You fail to mention the *real* reason At&t is raising their prices and lower their allowed data bucket One of the new features of the new iPhone that will be presented next week is a front facing video camera. If every iPhone user is still on an unlimited data plan, they might be tempted to video chat with each other for big stretches of time. Using the new feature will now be expensive for new iPhone users. Because they will use more data then they use now. Also, because the phone will be faster browsing will be even more pleasurable (it is on my iPad although that might partly be because the bigger screen).

AT&T is afraid they can't sustain all that data. They have problems right now in many locations.

I'd be fine with the carriers moving away from unlimited plans if they did so in a simple and customer friendly way. I should be able to carry as many communication devices as I want and share the minutes/megabytes amongst them without tethering charges, family plan surcharges, etc... This would create an explosion of devices and applications that all utilize the carriers wireless services - benefiting everybody including the carriers.

Imagine if ISPs hadn't allowed home routers/NAT (I remember when they tried to resist them) and had forced customers to pay for every IP address? We wouldn't have the rich breadth of data appliances we have today.
